paragraphs: This paper studies the impact of environment taxes and market competition on firms' choices of a clean technology. Specifically, we model two profit-maximizing firms competing with each other in a duopoly market where the firms charge the same price and face a common price-dependent demand. The firms play a two-stage game in the following sequence. In the first stage (technology game), the firms choose from two available technologies which differ in environmental emissions as well as in the fixed and variable costs. In the second stage (production game), depending on the technology choices, firms simultaneously choose optimal production quantities, given an exogenous environmental tax rate set by a regulator. We show that a priori symmetrical duopolist may choose the same or different technologies, depending on the tax rate and other parameters, and clean and normal technologies may coexist in equilibrium. Contrary to common belief, switching to the clean technology is not always a best response to an increase in the tax rate. We find that the firms' reaction to an increase in the tax rate may be non-monotone. We also show that the tax rate range for both firms to adopt clean technology is narrower than that in the monopoly case, which suggests that the regulator needs to be more precise in setting tax rate to motivate all firms to switch to the clean technology when there exist competition. relies on the assumption that production level is fixed. They show that optimal policy depends on various parameters and firm response. Reference [4] also shows that policy optimality is a function of technology parameters. A number of research focuses on the impact of specific regulatory policy on firm activities. Reference [5] studies the impact of wind-electricity supply uncertainty on firm adoption. Reference [6] studies the impact of initial allocation of emission rights on firm production. Reference [7] uses a two-stage model to study the impact of carbon tax and carbon emission right on capacity investment. They show that the uncertainty of emission right price will not necessarily lower firm expected profit. Reference [8] studies how to use environmental taxation to provide proper incentives for firms to make the "right" technology choices. They show that firm's reaction to an increase in taxes may be non-monotone: while an initial increase in taxes may motivate a switch to a greener technology, further tax increases may motivate a reverse switch; supplementing the environmental taxation with fixed cost subsidies and consumer rebates can expand the range of parameters over which the green technology is chosen and often close the welfare gap to the centralized solution.

paragraphs: Environmental issues are becoming one of the most important factors when companies make important business decisions, such as investment and technology choice. Many industries have developed various alternative technologies to reduce pollution. However how to incentivize companies to choose these technologies is not straightforward. Regulators may use various tools, such as environmental taxes, fines, subsidies, consumer rebates, and cap-and-trade mechanisms, to achieve regulatory objectives. Each of these tools may have its own pros and cons depending on specific industry structure, implementation feasibility, policy parameters, and more importantly the strategic response of the regulated bodies.

References and study the impact of different regulatory policies on the adoption of new pollution-abating technologies. They rank policy effectiveness in the following order: auctioned permits, taxes and subsidies, free permits, and emission standards. Reference points out this conclusion This paper builds on , and incorporates the effect of industry competition on "green" (clean) technology adoption and policy design. Specifically, we model a duopolist who first make technology decisions and then compete in a Cournot quantity game, given an exogenous environmental tax rate set by the regulator. We show that the duopolist may choose the same or different technologies, depending on the tax rate and other financial parameters, clean and normal technology may coexist in equilibrium. Contrary to common belief, a clean technology is not always the best response to tax rate increases. We find that the firms' reaction to an increase in tax rate may be non-monotone: an initial increase in tax rate may motivate just one firm to switch to the clean technology, but its competitor may keep the technology choice unchanged. Further rate increases then motivate the unchanged firm to choose the green technology too. After that, tax rate increases may motivate a reverse switch, again first just one firm switches back to the normal technology, and then followed by the other one.

Our findings show that market competition complicates firms' technology choices. We find that in two disjoint tax rate ranges, normal and clean technologies coexist in the market, although the "normal" firm has a lower profit than the "clean" one, it does not switch to the clean technology because if the normal firm also switch to the clean technology, it will lead to fiercer competition and even lower profit for the firm. paragraphs: In this paper, we consider the models of a monopoly and a duopoly acting in response to environmental taxation imposed by a regulator. The firms are risk neutral and make a two-stage decision to maximize their expected profits. In the first stage, the firms can either invest in a clean technology (C) that allows them to produce with higher costs but less pollutant emission or in a normal (dirty) technology (N) which produces with lower costs but emits more pollutant. Hereafter we use i, i = C, N, to denote the technology chosen by a firm. The fixed setup cost of technology i is K i , where K C > K N . For simplicity, we assume K N = 0, which will not influence our results and can be relaxed easily.

This assumption states that the condition on tax rate is stricter for a "normal" firm than for a "clean" firm to start production. That is, if a tax rate is optimal for a "normal" firm to start production, a "clean" firm will also start production, but not vice versa. This assumption is reasonable since otherwise for given technology choice i, the taxes motivate a "normal" firm instead of a "clean" firm to produce. From the point of view of our model, this is not an interesting case. Actually we can verify that if this assumption is violated, the firm will always choose a normal technology in the first stage. paragraphs: Proposition 5 shows that the technology equilibrium gradually changes from , to (C, N), to (C, C), to (N, C), and to as the tax rate t increases. This result suggests that the effect of tax rate on technology choice is nonmonotone: a firm will choose normal technology when the tax rate is either too small or too large, which is consistent with the result of the monopoly case. The result of Proposition 5 also suggests that, besides t, a firm's technology choice takes into consideration of the choice of its competitors: when t is not too small or too large, two firms choose different technologies; only when t takes an intermediate value, both firms choose the clean technology. The asymmetric technology-choice case is interesting since it highlights the effect of market competition on technology choice: for some t, when one firm switches to a clean technology, another firm may not follow suit, since the (C, C) choice results in a lower profit for the "normal" in the (C, N) choice. Therefore although the "normal" firm now has a lower profit than the "clean" firm, it may not necessarily switch to the clean technology. paragraphs: Market competition also has an effect on the tax rate range over which at least one firm chooses the clean technology. We observe that condition for both firms to adopt clean technology is a sufficient condition for condition (5), but not vice versa, which suggests that the tax rate range that induces all firms to adopt the clean technology is narrower in the duopoly than in the monopoly case. In duopoly case, though the tax rate range that induces at least one firm to adopt the clean technology is wider than the range that induces a monopolist to adopt the clean technology, inducing both firms to adopt the clean technology requires narrower rate range. The reason is that in the duopoly case, competition lowers the benefit for the "normal" firm to switch to the clean technology when its rival has adopted the same technology, thus the switching only makes economic sense when the tax rate (penalty on the normal technology) is even higher.

This finding is valuable to the regulator. A tax rate that induces a monopolist to adopt the clean technology may not induce all firms to adopt the technology when market competition is present. If the regulator's goal is to induce all firms switch to the clean technology, it has to set the tax rate more precisely or consider subsidizing the fixed cost or the variable cost of the clean technology.

There are many directions this paper can be extended. First it would be desirable to extend the model to many firms. Then we can study the link between environmental policy parameters and the adoption rate of "green" technology in industry. "Green" technologies increase overall production costs, thus in the long term might result in some firms exiting the market. Fewer incumbents suggests lower industry competitiveness and might be detrimental to social welfare. A model that considers many firms might help to quantify this effect. Second the regulator can be incorporated into the model as a decision maker. It might be interesting to compare how the optimal tax rate changes in response to the market competitiveness. Third this paper only studies one policy instrument, environmental tax rate. We may extend it to consider a model that collectively optimizes several policy tools under different market competitiveness, which could generate some insights that help to coordinate different regulatory tools in answering to different market conditions.

paragraphs: In this paper we build a model that incorporates competition into firms' "green" technology adoption decision. We find the non-monotone technology choice in a monopoly, i.e., a firm will choose normal technology when the tax rate is either too small or too large, still persists in a duopoly market. But more importantly we show that for some tax rate, the a priori symmetric firms may choose different technologies: one choose the clean technology and the other the normal technology, in equilibrium. The reason behind is that market competition lowers the gains for the "normal" firm switching to the clean technology, so it has to postpone adoption unless offered an even higher environmental tax rate. We further show that the tax rate range for both firms to adopt clean technology is narrower than that in the monopoly case. Thus a tax rate that induces a monopolist to adopt the clean technology may not induce all firms to adopt the technology when market competition is present. If the regulator's goal is to induce all firms switch to the clean technology, it has to set the tax rate more precisely than in the monopoly case.
